trustfund: TF026361-PHRD-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040005-ROMANIA - FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040762-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040922-ROMANIA: FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forest Development Project
            objectives will be: (i) to improve the management of state
            owned forests through capacity building and technical
            innovation for environmentally-sustainable and cost
            effective forest management, and (ii) to support the
            establishment of pilot systems for forest management among
            underserved private forest owners. The following are changes
            in the Forest Development Project: (i) the project
            development objectives will be modified to reduce the
            sector-wide scope of planned interventions; (ii) envisaged
            support for the establishment of the Forest Sector Business
            Information Center will be dropped; (iii) support will be
            provided to design a Forest Geographic Information System as
            part of the Forest Management Information and Monitoring
            System (FMIMS); the planned program of forest roads
            rehabilitation will be scaled back; and (iv) support for
            private forest owners will be shifted to focus on groups of
            private owners of the smallest forest holdings, who
            generally lack capacity or the means for achieving economies
            of scale in forest management. The project support increased
            productivity and competitiveness of forest industries,
            through establishing and operating a Forest Sector Business
            Information Center (ForsBIC); and build public support for
            sustainable forest management by implementing a public
            awareness program targeting key stakeholders with an
            emphasis on new private forest owners. The project support
            for the development of a single national standard for
            sustainable forest management is being dropped, to allow for
            a diversity of national standards development.
